awd_titl_txt: Broadening STEM Participation Among Minority Students in a Urban Community College
awd_abstract_narration:
The Borough of Manhattan Community College/CUNY (BMCC) is an urban community college which qualifies as both a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI)and a Minority Serving Institution (MSI). It does not offer degrees beyond the baccalaureate level. The project entitled "Broadening STEM Participation Among Minority Students in an Urban Community College" will support quality education, mentoring and internship opportunities for an ethnically diverse population. This initiative builds on the undergraduate research experience for students developed and implemented by the University of Maryland-Baltimore County (UMBC) Meyerhoff program. This model of undergraduate research remains a novel concept for most community colleges. New knowledge will be added by BMCC research efforts, which will seek to determine the support programs that work to fully engage students and ensure that S-STEM interventions positively impact retention and graduation. As an alternative to research students will also be provided the opportunity to participate in off campus internships. Assignments will be developed by S-STEM faculty with input from the college's private industry partners. Students will work much like members of industry based teams, dealing with problems in areas of basic research, product development and testing, analytical technologies, risk assessment and regulatory compliance. Each intern will be supervised by company personnel and visited at the worksite by BMCC Cooperative Education Internship Coordinators. Sixty talented full-time students in Computer Science, Mathematics, Engineering and/or Science are expected to be recruited into the program and awarded a 2-year scholarship. 

Research indicates that an undergraduate research experience as a capstone experience undertaken by students during their final year of study is successful. The Meyerhoff program success is built upon the concept that by assembling a concentration of high achieving students in a tightly knit learning community, students continually inspire one another to do more and better. That program boasts a STEM retention rate of 86% which is twice the national average for all students and more than four times the average for African American students.  BMCC has already in place programs and initiatives to support students success. The project will examine closely how the use of a structured STEM pathway model involving the use of the learning communities, in tandem with the Winter Bridge program, and faculty mentored research can achieve the same outcomes as those commonly found at residential four-year colleges such as UMBC, and whether these reforms can be sustained and replicated. Ongoing data collection, abstraction, and analysis will allow the research team to examine in specific and measurable ways the extent to which S-STEM participants are effectively being served and the success of program activities on improved academic outcomes (e.g., achievement, retention, graduation, post-secondary school enrollment). Collected data will be used to demonstrate if this model is useful when applied in early stages (critical and decisive years) of STEM careers. The results of this project will have a profound effect in determining whether similar reforms can be adapted by a urban community colleges serving populations traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines.

inst.inst_name: CUNY Borough of Manhattan Community College
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: CUNY Borough of Manhattan Community College

por.por_cntn:
The BMCC S-STEM project provided scholarships to 109 academically talented STEM students with demonstrated financial need.

The project provided mentoring, tutoring and advisement to underrepresented students that improved their retention in STEM disciplines.

The project provided opportunity to engage in faculty mentored research in Science, Engineering and Technology to fifty-two (52) STEM Scholars.

All students who participated in research activities presented their findings in "Talk Science Seminars" organized by the project team, conferences and symposiums.

A total of 67 students graduated and transferred to senior colleges to pursue a bachelor's degree in a STEM field; 20 students transferred to senior colleges to pursue a bachelor's degree in a STEM field before graduating from BMCC. Thus, a total of 87 students have graduated or transferred.  There are 14 students still enrolled at BMCC and they are all on track to graduate in the 2021-22 academic year. A total of 8 students left the program (left BMCC, had their GPA fall below the minimum required to be a Scholar, became part-time, or changed to a non-STEM major).

The S-STEM Project has exceeded all five Quantitative Objectives:

Objective 1:  Increase from 60 to 70% one-year retention rates.

Results: The overall retention rate was 101/109 = 92.7%

Objective 2: Increase from 41 to 50% the transfer rate for STEM students.

Results: At the beginning of Fall 2021 term, 87/109 Scholars have graduated or transferred (79.8%) and once the 14 Scholar remaining have graduated the rate will be 92.7%.

Objective 3:  Increase from 15 to 30% the three-year graduation rate.

Results: At the beginning of Fall 2021 semester 67/109 Scholars have graduated for a rate of 61.5% and once the remaining 14 students graduate the rate will increase to above 74% (81/109).

Objective 4:  At the conclusion of the award 85% of the Scholars will have been retained, graduated or transferred in S-STEM related fields.

Results: The percentage of Scholars in S-STEM fields is 92.7% (101/109).

Objective 5:  A total of 106 students will have been awarded a scholarship.

Results: A total of 109 students were awarded scholarships.

Two central tenets of the BMCC S-STEM proposal were that the development of STEM cohorts and engagement in research experiences would have similar impacts on the two-year college students at BMCC as has been found by similar interventions at four-year colleges. Student survey responses from Years Two-Five together with the quantitative results on the rates of retention, transfer and graduation of BMCC students provide the evidentiarily data to answer this question.  

The BMCC Project outcomes shows that a structured research program, designed and delivered to freshmen and sophomore students, can have an impact on STEM students similar to that found for upper-level students at 4-year institutions.  In fact, it may be true that these impacts on first- and second-year students are greater than the effect found later in a student?s academic journey. This is because most STEM students leave the field during their first two years because they believe they are not capable of success, or they find the field to be uninteresting.  At BMCC the cohort building activities/support structures guide students to success, while the opportunities to engage in a significant undergraduate research project peek student's interest in STEM.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2021
Modified by: Anna Salvati
